# Open Source Your Culture

## *Practical steps for driving an open source culture within your company*

# OVERVIEW & PURPOSE

From code to culture: empower employees with open source principles. Drive successful change within companies and teams. 

# OBJECTIVES

1. Better efficiency   
2. More innovation  
3. Stronger Relationships  
4. Do more with less

# PRINCIPLES

1. Transparency  
2. Collaboration  
3. Release early and often   
4. Inclusive meritocracy   
5. Community

# STEPS 

**1: AUDIT AND CREATE (Crawl)**

1. Find every team that works directly or indirectly with the same audience you do.  Document questions in one shared spreadsheet:   
   1. OKRs   
   2. Expectations of you/ your team  
   3. Their definition of what you/your team does  
   4. How do they envision you all working together  
2. Share learnings cross-functionally in an open format (meeting \+ doc.) Bring everyone together to discuss alignment opportunity    
3. Clarify/ create a team page (via confluence OR docs OR whatever tool you prefer, just needs to be open for comments). Accounting for feedback amongst partner teams, clarify:   
   1. *Who* is on your team   
   2. *What* do you all do (Roles and responsibilities)  
   3. *How* to engage with you/ your team (i.e. is there a process?)   
   4. *Why* do you do it? (your objective, mission)   
   5. *How* (your strategy, key results)   
   6. *When* (your calendar)  
   7. *Where* is your team located

**2: ALIGN AND COALESCE (Walk)** 

1. Establish shared and transparent goals (From closed → open)   
   1. Share OKRs and team pages transparently with all peer teams. Ask for feedback and evolve to achieve further alignment.   
   2. Highlight shared goals; discuss and align on dependencies upfront where you ladder up to the same overarching goals.    
   3. Form one view of all OKRs amongst cross functional teams.   
2. Shared and open team (From I → We)   
   1. For comms tools (i.e. Slack/ MSFT Teams)   
      1. Keep all projects “open” channels   
      2. For teams: have a private if teams feel it is needed AND an open channel for other teams to engage with yours. Or just have an open channel.    
      3. For Cross-functional team across same audience (i.e. “DevX”) \- create one unified open work channel.   
         1. Example: At Docusign we have \#DevX  
      4. For Cross-functional team across same audience (i.e. “DevX”) \- create one unified open fun channel.   
         1. Example: At Docusign we have \#DevXfun  
   2. For meetings  
      1. Get a biweekly or monthly cadence among leads from all cross functional teams where goals and projects are discussed  
      2. Get a biweekly or monthly cadence along DRIs for data cross functionally to discuss and analyze how you ALL are tra  
      3. Bias to breaking down barriers and redundancies over what needs to be done vs who does it. Example: If there’s a dev content standup and a dev marketing content standup, combine them.   
      4. Share notes & outcomes whenever possible following meetings. Keep them open for colleagues to view/change/ add to/ edit.   
3. Shared and open operations (From redundant → rapid)   
   1. Bias to iterative and open tools and settings    
      1. Examples: Confluence, Gdocs/ slides/ notes/ calendar → visible & open, github, Miro, Figma.   
   2. Share results openly   
      1. Meetings are OK but given burnout and CF team being across time zones, try to reduce these as often as possible and push for asynchronous sharing.   
      2. Share via other mediums: Slack video, notes, email, recording, etc. 

**2: COMMUNICATE OFTEN, MOVE QUICKLY (RUN/SKI/ BACK FLIPS)** 

1. Transparent, direct and ongoing communication

   1. Keep doors open to critical cross functional team members. 

   2. Keep your calendar open as well for meetings that aren’t confidential so folks know when they can get time with you. 

   3. When kicking off projects, always ensure there are leads identified across teams and communicated openly (example: dev redesign will involve product, marketing, content, design, engineering, support.) Define who drives which function and ensure alignment. [Radical candor](https://www.radicalcandor.com/) to discuss any overlap is also important to address early/ often.

   4. Establish workflows where possible to encourage sharing and enabling projects and blockers to be surfaced often amongst wider team, along with cross-functional achievements celebrated. 

      1. Example: for my team we have the following workflow (which I copied from [Lauren Gil](https://www.linkedin.com/in/laurenagil/) at Slack)

         1.  ![:rose:][image1] Highlight: A recent win, something positive that happened.

         2.  ![:rose\_bud:][image2]  Potential: What are you looking forward to?

         3.  ![:thorn\_109742540:][image3] Challenge: Blockers and/or support you could use help with.

         4.  ![:priority-highest:][image4] Priority: What are your top 1-3 priorities this week?
